The author told the person they had something on their forehead, which was actually the ash cross. The person got mad, and the author is now wondering if they're the asshole for accidentally offending someone's religious practice. 

Now, the key points here are intent and knowledge. The author didn't know it was Ash Wednesday and had no malice. They were just pointing out a visible mark, not aware of its religious meaning. Even though they weren't part of the religion, their comment inadvertently pointed out a religious symbol, which the other person found offensive. 

But since the author didn't know the context, is that their fault? In many cases, people are expected to be respectful of religious practices even if they aren't part of the religion. However, the author had no way of knowing it was a religious symbol. On the other hand, maybe they could have considered that a mark on the forehead might be intentional and not just a smudge. 

But the situation is that the author didn't know it was Ash Wednesday. So, if they had no knowledge of the religious aspect, can they be blamed? Also, the person's reaction might be disproportionate if the author had no intent to offend. 

I think in this case, the author isn't in the wrong because they were unaware. However, maybe there's a social expectation to be respectful of others' religious practices. But since the author had no knowledge and no intent, it's more of an accident. The other person's reaction is about their own feelings towards their religion, not the author's malicious intent.
